metadata.title: Reprecipitation synthesis of luminescent CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites with enhanced stability

sections.text:

Reprecipitation synthesis of luminescent CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites with enhanced stability†
Gaoling Yang,‡a Qingsong Fan,‡a Bingkun Chen,b Qingchao Zhoua and Haizheng Zhong*a
Stability is one of the most serious intrinsic limiting factors for the
application of halide perovskites in optoelectronics. In this com-
munication, we introduce the concept of space localization to tackle
this problem by fixing the unstable organic methylamine cation using
inorganic salts. The obtained luminescent CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites exhibit enhanced stability against thermal and photo-
degradations.
As an emerging exceptional class of functional materials, organometal halide perovskites have attracted considerable attention for their attractive performance in low cost solution-processed optoelectronic devices such as photovoltaics,1–3 light-emitting diodes (LEDs),4–6 lasers,7,8 and photodetectors.9,10 They have cemented their position in the field of photovoltaics because of their ground-breaking conversion efficiency of over 20%,11 as well as their recorded wide color gamut in display technology.12 However, although the remarkable performance of these devices have been demonstrated, their practical applications are still hindered by the instability of organic–inorganic halide perovskites. Halide perovskites suffer from inherent instability and undergo extremely fast degradation under different exposures (moisture, UV light, solution and high temperature).13,14 This instability is more pronounced in perovskite nanocrystals (NCs) due to their larger surface area/volume ratio and higher surface activities. To improve the stability of perovskite NCs, many efforts have been made. For example, Li et al. enhanced the photostability of CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs by embedding them in silica spheres. 15 Zhang’s group used branched molecules as capping ligands to control the solution stability of organolead halide perovskite NCs.16 Our group developed an in situ fabrication strategy to
prepare perovskite/polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) composite films to improve the stability of perovskite NCs against water moisture and UV radiation.17 However, it remains a major concern to find solutions to address the issue of thermal stability for halide perovskites.
Perovskite NCs have already demonstrated their outstanding potential in backlight displays due to their ultra-high photoluminescence (PL) quantum yields (QYs), extremely wide color gamut, and tunable emission spanning the entire visible spectrum.12,18–21 However, in practical applications, the thermal encapsulation process of LEDs could barely be completed due to the thermal instability of perovskite NCs, let alone the color fading and CIE color coordinate shift under long time service or high bias. Under heat, organic methylamine cations in perovskites are likely to migrate, which usually lead to lattice disturbance and further degradation. Embedding preformed inorganic NCs into inorganic salts has been demonstrated to be an effective way of improving their thermal stability as well as the preservation of their optical properties.22–26 Here, we introduce the concept of space localization to solve this problem by embedding perovskites into ionic matrices via an in situ formation strategy. Under the protection of ionic matrices, the resulting CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites exhibit a remarkable improvement of the thermal and photo-stability. Moreover, using such high-quality nanocomposites as green phosphors, prototype LED devices with moderate performance were fabricated, suggesting the potential application of these nanocomposites in lighting and display applications.
We choose NaNO3 as the matrix because of its transparency, nontoxicity, and relatively low refractive index (1.34), and more important is that it can be dissolved in N-dimethylformamide (DMF), the most commonly used solvent for perovskite precursors. As shown in Scheme 1, we designed a one-step reprecipitation procedure to synthesize CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites. Firstly, 0.2 mmol of lead bromide (PbBr2), 0.16 mmol of methylammonium bromide (CH3NH3Br), 20 mL of n-octylamine, 0.5 mL of oleic acid (OA), 5 mL of DMF and 0.1 g of NaNO3 were mixed to form a precursor solution, and then a Beijing Key Laboratory of Nanophotonics and Ultrafine Optoelectronic Systems, School of Materials Science & Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China. 1 mL of precursor solution was poured into 30 mL of toluene under vigorous stirring at room temperature. The yellow precipitates were collected and air-dried after centrifugation at 6000 rpm for 3 min. Compared with previously reported approaches that typically needed 1–4 weeks to embed NCs into a NaCl matrix,22–25 our strategy is extremely fast, facile and efficient. In this method, when the poor solvent toluene was poured into the precursor solution, CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 composites were formed immediately from the solution due to their insolubility in toluene and accomplished in a few seconds. By scaling up the synthesis, the one-pot reaction can afford 2 g of green-emissive CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites (Fig. S1, ESI†). This protocol is suitable for industrialized production bearing the advantages of scalability, reproducibility and low-cost. The as-prepared nanocomposites are yellow powder under day light (Fig. 1a), and exhibited strong green PL when excited by the 365 nm UV light (Fig. 1b). We further varied the amount of oleic acid, NaNO3 and toluene to optimize the sample and achieved optimized PL QYs up to 42% (Fig. S2–S4, ESI†).
To investigate the structure of the resulting CH3NH3PbBr3/ NaNO3 nanocomposites, we performed structure measurements, morphology observations and elemental analysis by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The SEM images indicated that the resulting nanocomposites are 2–3 mm micrometer-sized particles (Fig. 1c and d). EDS spectra confirmed the formation of CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites (Fig. S5, ESI†). To illustrate the morphology of CH3NH3PbBr3 in the matrix, the resulting nanocomposites were embedded in polymer resin and cut into thin sheets for SEM characterization. The SEM images shown in Fig. 1e confirm that the as-fabricated CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs in the NaNO3 matrix are small particles with sizes ranging from 30 to 50 nm and homogenously distributed in the matrix. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs, NaNO3, and CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites. As expected, the characteristic XRD peaks of both cubic NaNO3 and CH3NH3PbBr3 crystal planes are observed in the as-prepared CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites. The average domain of CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs is
calculated to be about 26 nm from the XRD pattern according to 7 different peaks using the Scherrer formula where the k value was taken as 0.89 (Table S1, ESI†). The XRD estimation is in accordance with the SEM determination. To understand the formation process of the nanocomposites, we conducted controllable experiments to illustrate the influence of CH3NH3PbBr3 on the crystallization of NaNO3. As shown in Video S1 (ESI†), the crystallization of NaNO3 with

For the formation of the CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites, the phenomenon is very similar to the crystallization of CH3NH3PbBr3 (Video S3, ESI†). Based on material characterization studies and experimental observations, we proposed that the formation of CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 micrometer-sized nanocomposites might contain two steps. Firstly, CH3NH3PbBr3 precursors crystallized into 30–50 nm NCs and then induced a seeded crystallization of NaNO3 into 2–3 mm nanocomposites.
The PL emission and UV-Vis absorption spectra of CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs and CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites are shown in Fig. 3a. For CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites, a band edge at 525 nm and a narrow green emission peak at 526 nm with a full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) value of only 24 nm were observed. Compared with the emission peak of CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs at 515 nm, a small red shift of the emission maxima occurs, which may come from the change in NCs’ diameters (from 4 nm to 30 nm).12 We also measured the timeresolved PL spectra of CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs and CH3NH3PbBr3/ NaNO3 nanocomposites (Fig. 3b and c). The tri-exponential fitting of the PL decay gave an average recombination lifetime of B155.5 ns, which is much longer than that of pure CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs (B10.3 ns, Fig. 2b) and even bulk CH3NH3PbBr3 films (B100 ns).27 Such a prolonged lifetime indicated a significant reduction of nonradiative channels in the perovskite NCs, which may be attributed to the efficient surface passivation of the tight NaNO3 matrix.
Besides surface passivation, the NaNO3 matrix also makes the perovskite highly resistant to heat and light, which are extremely important in practical applications of photonic and optoelectronic devices. To test the thermal stability, the PL intensity changes of CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs and CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites were recorded at 100 1C. As shown in Fig. 4a, the pure CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs lost 99% of their PL intensity within 50 min (PLQYs less than 0.6%), while the nanocomposites lost only 20% of their initial PL intensity at the same time interval (PLQYs of 36.4%). After 5 h, the CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites can still maintain about 30% of their original value (PLQYs of 12.7%). According to the statistics, it can be concluded that the nanocomposites show improved thermal stability in comparison with pure perovskite NCs. The enhancement can be attributed to
the introduction of ionic matrices. In the nanocomposites, organic methylamine cations are space localized and stabilized in the confined space under heat, which prohibits the lattice disturbance or degradation.
The photostability test was implemented under continuous UV-light (365 nm, 6 W) illumination. As shown in Fig. 4b, after 14 h irradiation, the PL intensity of CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs decreased to 10% (PLQYs, 2.7%), while CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites still maintained 80% of their original value (PLQYs, 33.6%). The improved photostability of the CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites is likely attributed to the multiple protection effects of the tight NaNO3 matrix on CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs. The solution stability test was also conducted in polar solvent chloroform, as shown in Fig. S6 (ESI†); the relative PL intensity of CH3NH3PbBr3/ NaNO3 nanocomposites in chloroform remains almost 40% after 30 h (PLQYs, 13.8%), while that of CH3NH3PbBr3 NCs decreased to less than 10% (PLQYs, 3.1%). These results demonstrate that all the thermal, photo-, and solvent stability of CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites can be substantially improved using inorganic salt as the space localized matrix, which potentially benefits optical applications.

backlight displays.12,28–33 Unlike previous works relying on multilayered structures where each emitter was placed in separate layers, in this work, we mixed green-emitting CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites with red-emitting K2SiF6:Mn
4+ in silicone resin directly in the single down-conversion layer. The obtained electroluminescence (EL) spectrum of the resulting white light LED is shown in Fig. 5. Under the operation of 20 mA forward bias current, the fabricated white light LED shows a luminescence efficiency of 22.39 lm W 1, a CRI value of 86.6, and a CIE chromaticity coordinate of (0.28, 0.32). At the same time, the color gamut overlap of the National Television System
Committee (NTSC) space was approximately 127%, much higher than commonly used phosphor LEDs (NTSC 86%) and Cd-NC LEDs (NTSC 104%).34 We further determined the stability of the LED devices (Fig. S8, ESI†). The electroluminescence spectra show that the device exhibits an B50% degradation after 4 hours at a current of 20 mA, which is much better than that of CH3NH3PbBr3 NC based LEDs (usually working under 5 mA). However, the performance is still far from the realized applications and need to be further investigated.
In summary, we have successfully fabricated brightly luminescent CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites through a reprecipitation approach, which is facile, reproducible, of low-cost, and scalable. Due to the space localization and protection of the tight matrix, the nanocomposites show enhanced thermal, light, and solvent stability. By mixing green-emitting perovskite nanocomposite powder and red-emitting KSF phosphor directly, wide color gamut LEDs with NTSC values reaching up to 127% were fabricated. We believe that perovskite/inorganic-salt nanocomposites provide a strategy to solve the stability problem and may pave the way for practical application in display backlights and other possible photonic devices.

metadata.abstractText: Stability is one of the most serious intrinsic limiting factors for the application of halide perovskites in optoelectronics. In this communication, we introduce the concept of space localization to tackle this problem by fixing the unstable organic methylamine cation using inorganic salts. The obtained luminescent CH3NH3PbBr3/NaNO3 nanocomposites exhibit enhanced stability against thermal and photodegradations.
